sentences.sentence: Readers offer personal glimpses of life in the South.

Also: Senators who tested positive for Covid; Afghanistan's lesson; hydrogen and the climate.To the Editor:Re “Vaccine Refusers Are Testing My Love of the South,” by Anton DiSclafani (Opinion guest essay, Aug. 14):Ms. DiSclafani's essay correctly confronts common canons of the South.
I was born in Raleigh, N.C., grew up in a small town on the Carolina coast and have returned here to live from time to time.

It's hard for me to feel affection for any of the elements that others claim to love about the South.The legacy of racism and a stubborn resistance to science and the facts while clinging to religious superstitions and prejudices to justify bigoted behavior does the South no credit.

As Ms. DiSclafani's experience illustrates, these characteristic Southern attitudes are highlighted by responses to the pandemic.Southern graciousness and courtesy have always been something of a facade, inauthentic and extended only to the chosen few.
If you love excessive heat, humidity and biting insects, then the South is the place for you.
Southern cuisine?

If excessive fat, salt, sugar, starch and other unhealthy ingredients are your cup of tea, then waddle on up to the table.It seems to me that most of the attributes associated with the South are best discouraged and disparaged rather than lauded.

In my experience, the best Southern locations and experiences are the ones that are the least Southern.Steven BellMorehead City, N.C.To the Editor:There are counties in New York, and even densely populated neighborhoods in New York City, with low vaccination rates.
There is plenty of balking about masks.

And there is racism in many major Northern population centers.It's fair to lament the problems where you live, but we need to stop demonizing others or making assumptions about people based on geography or the political orientation of their government officials.Edward AbahoonieSparkill, N.Y.To the Editor:I wasn't born in Texas, but “got here as fast as I could” (as a local saying goes), so Anton DiSclafani's essay resonated with me.I, too, was charmed by how welcoming my wife and I found Houston when we moved here from Washington, D.C., in 1999.
The cosmopolitan nature of the Bayou City impressed and delighted us.

We have two happy, thriving teenagers who have lived only in the Lone Star state.But the complete takeover of the state government by anti-science extremists has left me feeling much like Ms. DiSclafani ᅳ worried that we live in a deeply troubled place.We will likely remain in Houston at least until our son graduates from high school in two years.

After that, we may get out of here as fast as we can.Chris FerrisHoustonSenators With CovidTo the Editor:Re “Three Vaccinated Senators Test Positive for the Virus” (news article, Aug. 20):While vaccinated senators have tested positive lately for Covid, we should be thankful that the vaccines worked as planned.
The senators were kept out of the hospital and experienced only mild symptoms.

They're not debilitated and remain working for us because they were vaccinated.If we want a restored economy, children back to school and a nation in good health, we should all be vaccinated.George L. SantangeloStillwater, N.Y.The Lesson of AfghanistanTo the Editor:In a democracy, the debacle in Afghanistan is not merely the fault of four presidents.

It is our fault.We need to rethink the meaning of the military draft and stop delegating wars to the “professionals” fed by the military-industrial complex's insatiable appetite for profits and power.Having lived through the lies and misadventures of Vietnam, I believe that the endgame was forced by overwhelming public rejection of sending yet more of our children to die for a cause completely detached from America's well-being.We yawned through Iraq and Afghanistan because we are apparently too lazy and apathetic to fight political stupidity and chicanery unless the lives of all our children are on the line.

Reinstate national service and make it universal, and every parent and child over 18 will pay close attention to military commitments that risk their lives.Tama ZornBrookline, Mass.From the Energy Dept.

: Making Hydrogen Viable to Fight Climate ChangeTo the Editor:Re “Hydrogen's Status as Fuel of Future May Be in Doubt” (news article, Aug. 13):Much more work is necessary for hydrogen to become a low-cost, low-emissions energy carrier, but we also know that it holds great potential, particularly for harder-to-decarbonize sectors like industrial manufacturing.The U.S. Department of Energy is engaged in urgent and far-reaching research, development, demonstration and deployment efforts so hydrogen can become a critical tool to help confront the climate crisis.Our new hydrogen “Earthshot” aims to reduce the cost of hydrogen produced by renewable sources to $1 per kilogram by 2030.

At the same time, we are working to significantly cut greenhouse gas emissions, including methane, from natural gas-sourced hydrogen.The department is already partnering with other federal agencies, industry, universities and the department's National Labs to cut methane emissions throughout the natural gas supply chain.

We want to use this same collaborative approach for building out hydrogen hubs and quickly scaling up clean, cost-effective hydrogen.These are bold goals, but if government, the private sector and researchers work together, we're confident that we can reach them.

The climate crisis and the prosperity of our communities demand such ambition.David M. TurkWashingtonThe writer is the deputy secretary of energy.PHOTO:    (PHOTOGRAPH BY Nick Oxford for The New York Times FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)
